The athletes of today are not only much better than those of the past, they also look incredibly different. The weird thing is, scientists know that the human body hasn’t evolved that dramatically in the past one hundred years. So why do Olympic athletes look so different now compared to the first winter Olympics in 1924?

2 – In the early 1900s, the ideal athlete was based on classical human proportions. If we imagine body types distributed as a bell curve with extreme body types being on the far ends, it was the middle of the curve that was considered the best physical build. Athletes who were not too tall but not too short, not too bulky but not too skinny and well, average, were deemed as ideal for the Olympic pursuit.

3 – But this has all changed. Now, athletes succeed based on their highly specialized body types which allow them to excel in a world of growing competitiveness. For example, athletes who are required to spin in the air such as figure skaters or gymnasts have been getting smaller. These athletes with short specialized body types have an advantage over average or tall athletes, weeding them out at the elite level.

4 – In fact, in thirty years, the average professional gymnast has shrunk from 5,3ft to 4,9ft. Computer simulations studying the physics of ski jumping have proven that jump length increases drastically with a decrease in body weight. Throughout recent years, this has caused world class ski jumpers to become extremely underweight, including many examples of anorexia.

5 – With women competing in the Olympic ski jumping event for the first time this year, their bodies are stockier and broader than their male counterparts. As female ski jumping becomes more popular and competitive in the future, it’s likely we’ll see the extremely thin ski jumping body type dominate the sport.

6 – Hockey is also an example of visible body changes. Studies looking at the past 26 years alone found a steady increase through the years of nearly all variables measured. This included height, mass, body mass index, aerobic and anaerobic fitness and even grip strength. Since the 1920s hockey players have increased nearly four inches on average from 5,9 to 6,1ft.

7 – So clearly the Average Joe Olympian is a thing of the past. But science says the games may now be a realistic goal for people of many different sizes and shapes. Don’t forget we have a new video out every day during the Olympics. Can’t wait? Our amazing partners at the CBC already have five of the videos up now for you to binge on.

8 – Just head to cbc.ca/Olympics/ScienceSays to watch them before anyone else. Link in the description. But we also want to know your questions for this special series. Use the hashtag ScienceSays and let us know your burning Olympic questions and subscribe for more awesome science videos.

no surprise that the oversimplified superfreak argument is being added to in these comments by the steroids thing.  these are the olympics.  you can't juice and compete.  you can't even take trace amts of the wrong decongestant and not get busted.  i competed at a serious level in skiing and trust me it's no basic pee-in-a-cup-and-dip-the-strip situation. at the olympic level its 100% insurmountable gas chromatography testing for a multi-page litany of banned substances.  also, small and skinny might help you cut through the air like a blade once you're off the jump, but the detriment it causes in actually getting to the lip with good speed pretty much negates the advantage.  it's popular these days to tar elite sporting with the brush of freakish, dishonest unfairness to make lazily assing out on the web (as i do nowadays more than not) seem a bit less slothful, but it's just not accurate.  just as many top games athletes are of normal proportion.

This is interesting. I am from Lake Placid NY, home of the Winter Olympics in 1932 and 1980. I grew up with Olympians. I agree their bodies are very different today from when my grandfather competed and won in bobsledding in the 40s through the 60s and he is different from my father who competed in the 80s and 90s. I myself am a marine biologist who does not do even come close to the physical activities my father does, even today. He is a very fit old man, where I am a very thin nerd. I know many families like mine with generations of athletes, it would be interesting to see where genes play a roll in their achievements. I often joke that I have an Olympian metabolism. Also, to comment on your chances of becoming an Olympian video it is easy when you grow up in towns that place athletic abilities above academic achievements, the way Lake Placid does.

The Olympics is an odd beast. Maybe in antiquity, or just early in the 20th century, one could work hard, make the right connections and have a little luck to be selected to become an Olympic athlete, and represent their country at the Games. Fast forward to our era of forced hyper-globalization, and you'll notice that the difference between those who get gold and those who get nothing could be a matter of a fraction of a second.

Athletic competition has intensified to such an extent that genetics is now the sole deciding factor as to who wins and who is completely forgotten. A matter of a single nucleotide out of three billion could be the difference between an amateur diver and a gold medalist. There are a number of traits that are directly related to athletic performance, for example, those that involve erythropoietin signalling; this hormone pathway modulates the number of available red blood cells in the body at all times. Some athletes have genetic conditions that cause this hormonal system to be over-activated for whatever reason -- the result is equivalent to "blood doping".

Imagine having trained your entire life, investing every dime and moment of free time you had in order to become good at what essentially boils down to just one single Olympic event. You got to the top of the local listings, the state/provincial listings, then the national listings, and then, finally, an entire lifetime of work pays off, and you get a spot at the next Olympic games in your event.

The truth is, it matters precisely fuck all these days. The person next to you trained just as hard as you, followed the same steps as you, and deserves it just as much as you. The only difference between you and them is... a hormonal receptor allele. They take the gold, you end up with 4th or 5th place, and are soon completely forgotten.

Now you understand why high-level athletes take 'extra measures' to ensure 'top performance'. It makes no sense anymore to shame or despise them; what they're doing is just emulating the accidental natural 'tweak' that is the favorable genetic makeup of some lucky, extremely rare person, somewhere in the multitude of people in the world.

Now that's one awful state of affairs, at least in my opinion. It takes everything away from what was once a good-natured international competition that most people could relate with and cheer for. Today it's just a matter of pitting these tortured creatures against each other to see who just happens to have the right mutation in the right place. There will come a time when every genetically favorable allele for Olympians will be discovered and described -- and at that point there is just no point in having the Games at all, because the outcome is predetermined. At some point we have to realize that, maybe, just maybe... we pushed it a bit too much.
A fresh look at the Olympics

There was no specialized training in 1924.  What training they did was very limited since people had to earn a living and didn't have Olympic training camps and facilities to use.  There was no sponsorship money for the athletes or stipends.

The equipment has improved dramatically since 1924.  You put 1924 equipment on modern athletes and the modern athletes wouldn't fair much better if any.

Nutrition and PEDs are also major factors, probably the biggest factors. 

Facilities where the games are held are much better.  More consistent, highly engineered.

Athletes are more motivated now because they stand to make a lot of money.  In 1924 you did it for true competition.
 
Personally I would rather watch the 1924 Olympics.  Real everyday people who were competitive and had skills that were developed a lot more naturally.

I know you guys are scientists, not punctuation experts. However, please note that plural years used to connote a decade do not use apostrophes. Therefore, it's 1920s not 1920's. An apostrophe makes it possessive like "Tom's hat." No apostrophe makes it plural like "hats."

The reason for hockey players increase in the last 26 years is very simple. Prior to the 1988 Winter Olympics hockey was intended for only amateurs and professional players were not allowed. So after that it would obviously increase drastically when professionals take the jobs instead.

There would also be another jump in 1998 when the NHL allowed its players to compete as well since it includes the top hockey athletes in the world. Another important thing to note involves the standard for athletes in all sports across the world. It was not long ago that one of the greatest NHL players Mario Lemieux was a smoker.

Along with that training has improved dramatically too and with more competition as a result of the growth of the game, the bigger and the stronger are more likely to succeed.

I'd hesitate calling some of these statements downright "facts". Many of them are debated theories with notable alternative explanations. For example, the last statements in this video are merely deterministic perspectives to questions of much debate.

I, for one, believe in them in the light of all the evidence and scientific support. But you shouldn't just state them as absolute facts, ignoring all alternative theories. That's what many dogmatic religious teachings are based on and it's not what rational people who believe in empirical and logical evidence should start doing.
